snippet.textDisplay: I have never been as shaken (in a good way) by a game in my life, and I've played a lot of games.  This game really is a piece of art.  With the one exception of wishing there was a minimap and an easier way to get a reminder of your current objective, this game is perfect.  The characters, the plot, the mechanics, the art, the sound, the voice acting... every single element fires on all cylinders and then some.  Y'all simply must play it.

snippet.textDisplay:
I played this for like 3 hours. Good game. But has a few annoying things.

- One thing that really really annoyed me is that you have to press [Next] after every single word anyone says, or sigh they make, even though there is no dialogue options there. 
So you can't just take a sip, or have a bite, or pet your dog, or stretch for a sec... you know what I mean. You have to keep your finger on stand-by, on the keyboard at all times.

- Another annoying thing is that you cannot click on the UI for Items/Skills/Attack. You can only press the assigned keys.
It would be great if you could select those via both keyboard or mouse at all times.

- I also don't love the fact that there are "whack-a-mole" elements within the duels, like the parry/dodge and perfect strike.
I personally like my turn-based games to be turn-based, and my action games to be actiony.
But I don't hate this hybrid combat. It's just not my favorite.

- The UI/X is exactly what I dislike in games in the last 10 years.
They are all made for controllers. And mouse/kb users have to deal with the gimpiness.
Things like having two pages of skills, instead of having them all on the screen, each with a keybind.
Meanwhile their icons block half the screen, just to make it look ...dynamic? 
What happened to a good old UI elements neatly tucked near the edges of the screen?
What happened to everything placed within a single action's reach? Instead of this clunky, unergonomic, "layered" Inception style of navigating everything... in/in/in/select the thing/out/out/out. You know what I mean.


Now here are the things that annoyed my wife, who likes to watch:

- Too much dialogue and very slow talking. I don't entirely disagree.

- Dialogue ends up choppy and unnatural due to the frequency at which you have to press [Next], when you shouldn't have to.

- Everyone looks like they are siblings and have the same face. (LMAO)

- The main guy has huge pores! Gamebreaking I know :)

- Why are we looking through a "widow's veil" or "bug screen" all the time? This is where I found and disabled the "film grain" setting.

- The main guy's name should have been "Jake Pattinson" or "Robert Gyllenhaal". Yup.

- Oh yeah, and people's hair look like cotton candy. Apparently, something about the edges.

The character development and relation building is the main thing here that I would love to see in other rpgs as well. 
Unfortunately the battles are technically a button masher of quick time events which I did not like. I felt like my own attacks weighted little in those battles and since I played with the keyboard pressing "E" or "Q" at the right moment decided of the fate of my team or the enemy every time.

I downloaded this on game pass without knowing anything about it. I just thought "I'll play the tutorial while I wait for Oblivion to download.

10 hours later and I can confidently say this might be game of the year. Just the prologue made me almost tear up. The characters are realistic and deep. The combat is always throwing new mechanics at you so you don't get bored. And the storyline is nothing short of a masterpiece. Only thing I can think about at work is being able to get home and start playing again.

snippet.textDisplay: It's such a shame the timing of the release. More people will buy and play Oblivion Remastered for the sheer nostalgia value, but when it comes down to it it's still a clunky game from 2006 with a new paintjob and there's nothing really new or exciting to discover. Expedition 33 is a wonderful breath of fresh air, it's Final Fantasy meets Nier Automata with Victorian/Art Deco flair, gorgeous characters, beautiful music and art direction, god tier voice acting and writing that really tugs on the heartstrings. Just a masterpiece of a game.

Just a masterpiece of a game.

snippet.textDisplay:
I bought this game twice. once for me, of course, and again for a friend. Because that‚Äôs what happens when a game is actually good. When it‚Äôs made with care, with heart, with passion. You want to support it. You want to share it.

We want solid gaming experiences that respect our time, our money, and our intelligence. Not this trend of live service, microtransaction-infested slop.

Gamers aren‚Äôt asking for much. Just give us something with soul and, most importantly, fun. I can say that Clair Obscur is fun and has that rare spark of soul and passion. Something that most triple A games don‚Äôt seem to have lately.

snippet.textDisplay: That timing system has got me having some tense battles. But once I ge it down its sooo good. It gives the battles a sense that they are more than just turned based because you can mitigate dmg with well timed dodges and parries so you have to focus. You don't just passivly watch the enemies turn happen. Its frustrating when yo don't nail the timing and soooo rewarding when you do. I can see streamers trying no damage runs if its possible to either dodge or parry every attack.
